Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sequence Selective Recognition of Double-Stranded Non-Coding RNA via Triplex Forming PNA
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding a collaborative effort between Eriks Rozners of Binghamton University and Paul F. Agris at the University at Albany to develop new methods for the study of RNA molecules, specifically those termed non-coding. RNA is one of several major classes of biopolymers present in living systems where it plays important functions. One of the best known functions is of information transfer from DNA to proteins in the translation step of gene expression. The RNAs used in this process are called coding (of proteins). Recently many non-coding RNAs have been discovered although the function of these RNAs has not been identified yet. The proposal of Rozners and Agris describes a method for the identification of non-coding RNAs that have a double helix structure using peptide nucleic acids (PNAs). The proposal builds on the recent discovery made by the PIs that single stranded (ss) PNAs can form triplexes with double stranded (ds) RNA that are more stable than triplexes formed by PNA with DNA. These structures can help reveal more details about RNA and its specific roles in metabolism and cell function and can have a broader impact in the development of new tools for biology and medicine. The project is having a further broad impact by providing balanced hands-on training to several graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary research area, thus preparing these students for technology-oriented future work.

The focus of the research is to develop PNAs, synthetic analogues of DNA, that bind double-stranded non-coding RNA with high sequence selectivity. Most non-coding RNAs fold in double-stranded conformations and molecular recognition of such structures is a difficult problem. Designing small molecules that selectively recognize RNA using hydrophobic or electrostatic interactions has been a challenging process. On the other hand, hydrogen bond mediated base pairing, which is a key feature of nucleic acids, has been underutilized in molecular recognition of RNA. Since the nucleobases of RNA are already base paired in the double helix, the most selective and straightforward sequence readout for ds RNA would be the major groove triple helix formation. Peptide nucleic acid, PNA, forms highly stable and sequence selective triple helices with double-stranded RNA at physiologically relevant conditions. The specific goals of this project are to: (1) study the triple helical recognition of mixed pyrimidine-purine tracts of RNA using nucleobase-modified PNA; (2) study the RNA binding and cellular uptake of PNA conjugated to cationic peptides; and (3) explore the molecular recognition of PNA-RNA triplexes with the goal of using the structural information for future rational design of new and better RNA binders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While less than 2% of DNA encodes for functional proteins, >70% is transcribed into so called non-coding RNA that is not further translated in proteins. The biological function of these structurally complex RNA molecules is not well understood, but the emerging view is that they play important roles in regulation of gene expression during normal development, as well as stress and disease. Selective binding, detection and functional inhibition of such regulatory RNAs would be highly useful for fundamental biology and practical applications in biotechnology and medicine. However, most non-coding RNAs fold in double-stranded conformations and molecular recognition of such structures is a formidable problem. In this project, we developed peptide nucleic acids (PNA), chemically modified DNA analogues, that can selectively bind and functionally modulate non-coding RNA.

The most significant discovery we made was that cationic nucleobase modification (replacement of the natural cytosine with 2-aminopyridine) enabled triple helical binding of PNA in the major groove of double-stranded RNA with high affinity and excellent sequence selectivity at physiological conditions. Moreover, an unexpected result was that our modified PNAs had unique preference for binding double-stranded RNA because binding to the same sequence of DNA was up to two orders of magnitude less favorable. This is important because it enables using our PNAs in biological systems without concern of off-target binding to double-stranded DNA. We also found that conjugation of our PNAs with short cationic peptides increased their uptake in live cells. An unexpected result was that the PNAs having cationic nucleobase modifications alone, without peptide conjugation were also taken up by cells. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of heterocyclic nucleobase modification that enhances the cellular uptake of PNA. This is important because poor cellular uptake of unmodified PNAs is one of the major roadblocks for their practical applications.

In collaboration with Japanese colleagues, we demonstrated that triple helical binding of PNA inhibited translation of messenger RNA and reduced the maturation of microRNA precursors. These are important results of the first proof-of-concept experiments for biological activity of triplex forming PNAs that may enable novel ways of controlling gene expression. Remaining challenges that we were not able to address in the current project are lack of detailed three-dimensional structure of PNA-RNA triple helix, endosomal entrapment of our PNAs after cellular delivery, and limitations to RNA sequences that can be recognized by our PNAs. These challenges are being addressed in related research projects that continue in our laboratory.

As part of this project we established two new collaborations: with Prof. Naoki Sugimoto at FIBER, Konan University, Kobe, Japan and with Prof. James MacKay at Elizabethtown College, a primarily undergraduate institution. These collaborations enhanced our scientific productivity and offered unique training and educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. With support of a Supplement for International Collaboration, the team members visited FIBER, broadened the expertise in RNA biochemistry and learned new laboratory techniques. Overall the project provided training for six graduate and six undergraduate students. Two students graduated with PhD thesis and the one undergraduate researcher co-authored a research paper in a peer reviewed journal. Both collaborations are continuing beyond the present project and will expand both intellectual merits and broader impacts of future activities in our laboratory.

Taken together, the results of our project suggest that the modified PNA-peptide conjugates are promising probes for sequence selective recognition of double-stranded RNA in live cells and other biological systems. Future developments may open the door to new ways for RNA recognition, imaging and functional control, which will find multiple applications in fundamental science, biotechnology and medicine.
